description:
Masterless samurai Akitsu Masanosuke is a skilled and loyal swordsman, but his naïve, diffident nature has more than once caused him to be let go by the lords who employ him. Hungry and desperate, he agrees to become a bodyguard for Yaichi, the charismatic leader of a group calling itself “Five Leaves.” Although disturbed by the gang’s sinister activities, Masa begins to suspect that Yaichi’s motivations are not what they seem. And despite his misgivings, the deeper he’s drawn into the world of the Five Leaves, the more he finds himself fascinated by these devious, mysterious outlaws.

(Source: Viz Media)

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

node.description:
Aspired to become an animator simply because he wanted to draw for a living. Later enrolled to and graduated from Tokyo Animator Gakuin. He then joined [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207/) and debuted as an in-betweener in 1987 under the studio's name on [God Bless Dancougar](https://anilist.co/anime/5266/). Nakazawa soon left Magic Bus and went freelance. In 1993, he was involved in the establishment of Studio G-1, an animation studio founded by [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/). During his time there he participated in many of [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/)'s productions. Nakazawa got strongly influenced by Oobari during this time due to working under him on multiple occasions. Also unlike most animators at the time, Nakazawa wasn't really that shaped by [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s style, he was though, a huge fan of [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/)'s and [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s.

In 2002, Nakazawa made his directorial debut with Comedy, part of an anthology titled [Sweat Punch](https://anilist.co/anime/1072/), produced by [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/). The following year he directed both [Parasite Dolls](https://anilist.co/anime/1350/) jointly with [Naoyuki Yoshinaga](https://anilist.co/staff/115038/), as well as the animated part in Quentin Tarantino's movie, Kill Bill: Volume 1. This brought him a lot of international praise. He then got reached out to by director [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) of [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) fame, about the possiblity of taking part in the director's next work, [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/). Nakazawa accepted the offer and ended up being a crucial part of its production, handling the character designs and serving as the sole chief animation director on the show. He also directed, storyboarded and wrote the 15th episode. Ten years later in 2014, Nakazawa collaborated with Watanabe for the second time on [Terror in Resonance](https://anilist.co/anime/20661/), providing the character designs and working as an animation director on the series.

In recent years he has been closely involved with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fusatora2828) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/mangetsuhakase)

While attending Waseda University, Mochizuki became interested in animation and he joined the Waseda University Animation Association. In 1981, he began working for Ajia-do Animation Works. Mochizuki made his debut one year later when he acted as production director of the 1982 series Tokimeki Tonight. He went on to direct several of the magical girl series, including Magical Angel Creamy Mami. In 1986, he moved up to chief director with Hikari no Densetsu.

Mochizuki became known from the early 1990s as director of Ranma ½, Kimagure Orange Road and the Studio Ghibli TV movie Ocean Waves, he is also known for having directed Twin Spica, Zettai Shounen, the acclaimed World Masterpiece Theater series Porphy no Nagai Tabi. More recently he directed the noitaminA series House of Five Leaves in 2010 and Battery in 2016.

He currently divides his time between directing, writing scripts and acting as a series coordinator for various shows.

Married to [Masako Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/153654/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fusatora2828) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/mangetsuhakase)

After having graduated from Tokyo Designer Gakuin, she joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), and started off as an animator. She is noted as the first female mecha director, and one of the few female directors in the '80s alongside [Makoto Moriwaki](https://anilist.co/staff/109581/) and [Hiroko Tokita](https://anilist.co/staff/101903/).
Hideaki Muraoka is a Producer and production coordinator working for Bee Train Productions Inc.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nocturamayama)

Yamashita graduated from Kokugakuin University with a Major in History. He first started out in the industry in 1997 as a production assistant at JCF. Amazingly, he has never been formally trained in art. His talent for drawing was first discovered through various doodles and sketches he would make on company paperwork.

Yamashita's first project as an animator was on [the second Kochikame movie](https://anilist.co/anime/3547/). Some time later he went freelance. [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/) was the first project he worked on freelance. Around 2006, Yamashita joined [Bee Train](https://anilist.co/studio/5/) and started work as character designer and animation director on the TV show [Ginyuu Mokushiroku Meine Liebe Wieder](https://anilist.co/anime/771/). A short while later, the animation department at Bee Train was spun off into new company, [C-Station](https://anilist.co/studio/6074/), and Yamashita moved with it. Today he retains a seat at C-Station, but regularly contracts out to work on various external projects.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nocturamayama)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/01_chan)

He graduated from Yoyogi Animation school and joined Studio Junio afterwards. After leaving Studio Junio, he became a freelancer and often works with Studio Sunrise and GONZO.
In 2008, him and former GONZO producer Ikeda Touyo founded Encourage Films Co., Ltd, with a capital of 5 million yen.
Ikeda Touyo would serve as the representative director and president of Encourage Films. 
With the death of Ikeda Touyo, on February 17, 2013, he was appointed as the representative director and CEO of Encourage Films.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/01_chan)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/asakonishida) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/24387) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西田亜沙子)

Originating from Studio Muu.


Married to fellow animator [Seiichi Nakatani](https://anilist.co/staff/107409/Seiichi-Nakatani).
